The simple matter of fact is that saying "20,000 volts" sounds shocking (see what i did there?) but you can get 10x that from a watch battery if you wanted it, the point is the AMPS are so low it is negligible.

Electric power is measured in Watts or if you want to talk about 'doing work' (kinetic) with it, then Joules would also suffice. The measure of electrical power (watts) is defined as VOLTS x AMPS. Having 20,000 volts is absolutely meaningless (and he KNOWS this) without knowing the AMPS.

I think this is how it works:

The fact that this system can keep delivering energy for a theoretical infinite amount of time means that there also has to be a constant input of energy into the system. The only way energy is added to the system is by the pumps that add potential energy to the water by raising it up.
The origional small disbalance in charge between the two streams of water causes the two seperate metal structures to gain a disbalance in charge as well. This difference in charge influences the ions in the streams of water: in the negative stream the negative ions get slowed down due to the fact that they are coming from a positive place (the upper coil, where they want to be because of their charge) and are falling towards a negative place. In the positive stream it works the other way around.
The ions that are slowing down lose some of the energy they got from being lifted up by the pumps to their invironment, so it probably goes to the electrical energy stored in the disbalance in charge between the two metal structures

There is literally no way this statement can be wrong, it's simple physics.

I'm perfectly aware that a low amp, slow ticking charge of a few thousand volts isn't going to provide much benefit. But by combining this system with a larger power generator you make THAT one more efficient - is what I'm saying. So on a sufficiently large scale, this could help improve one of the major alternative energy sources on the planet to make it more viable.

....nope. considering the apparatus you are showing the amount of charges should always stay the same, because they exit the diffuser and now they are there...where does the excess positive charges come from? or how do negative charges manage to leave? if you want to create an imbalance the two sides must be connected, somehow. i'm not saying this apparatus doesn't work, i'm saying there must be something very important you forgot to tell us. (researching) oh, ok, here it is: the two sprincklers are connected, the water comes from the same reservoir. that means that electrons in the stream of water will flow towards the positively charged ring and flee the negatevely charged one, even if they have to run against the stream. 
you also didn't mention the most important characteristic of this splendid contraption: it works because a water stream becomes droplets as it flow down. this is paramount because in the upper stream (continous) charges are allowed to flow, as said previously, but when they are droplets if they have a net charge they retain it, it's this interruption in the ability of the electrons to flow that creates the charge imbalance.
also, it would have been neet if you had mentioned a couple of thingss:
1- the process doesn't violate the conservation of energy: part of the gravitational potential energy is transformed in electric potential.
2- the building up of charges works because the mesh and the coil attatched to it are made of a conductor material, with makes sure that the net charge is deposited on the outmost surface i.e. away from the stream of water that could recapture them. 
and finally: CREDIT THE INVENTOR! Lord Kelvin
